explanation: The report is correct. MISRA R.21.17 forbids string-handling code that can read beyond the bounds of the referenced object. MHD_create_post_processor calls MHD_lookup_connection_value_n(...,&encoding, NULL) which returns only a pointer to the stored header value (pos->value) but no size is requested or checked. MHD_str_equal_caseless_n_(literal, encoding, MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_(literal)) then indexes encoding[i] for i up to maxlen-1 and treats a zero byte as termination; if the stored header value is not NUL-terminated within that maxlen (or not terminated at all) the function will read past the actual value buffer and thus can perform out‑of‑bounds reads. The same lack of a guaranteed NUL terminator also makes the later calls to strstr(boundary, "boundary=") and strlen(boundary) unsafe. To be compliant the code must either obtain the value size and use bounded comparisons (memcmp / explicit length checks) or ensure a NUL-terminated copy of the header value is made before calling functions that expect C strings.
